person.note:
Categories:
People -- Charged with Criminal Activity
People -- Men

note.p: Dewitt Clinton Senter was a Unionist politician in Tennessee during the Civil War who served as governor during Reconstruction.

Born on March 26, 1830, in McMinn County, Tennessee, Senter attended Strawberry Plains College in the early 1850s and studied law. He became active in local politics by the mid-1850s, entering the Tennessee House of Representatives as a Whig in 1855 and serving until the outbreak of the Civil War in 1861. He vehemently opposed secession, and when Tennessee voted to separate from the Union, Senter participated in an effort to have the pro-Union eastern part of the Tennessee conduct its own secession from the rest of the state (similar to the separation of western Virginia counties from their state to make the new state of West Virginia in 1863).

Confederate authorities arrested Senter for his pro-Union sentiments and separatist actions in 1862. Upon release, he moved to Louisville, Kentucky, and joined the Republican Party. He returned to Tennessee in 1865, when it was largely under Union military control, and won election to the state senate.

In 1867, Senter became speaker of the senate. He initially allied with Radical Republican governor William Brownlow. When Brownlow won election to the U.S. Senate in 1869 and vacated the governor’s office, Senter’s role as speaker of the senate placed him next in line for the office. He became governor with a promise to fight rising Ku Klux Klan violence in Tennessee. Within weeks, though, Senter began adjusting his actions. He dissolved the state guard, which had been the primary force opposing the Klan, and advocated for the restoration of rights to former Confederates. His efforts split the Republican Party in Tennessee and led to an effort by Radicals to replace him during the election of 1869. Senter managed to win the election and in 1870 he oversaw a state constitutional convention, which affirmed the right for all men above 21 years of age to vote (regardless of race), but established a poll tax and racially segregated schools.

Senter’s handling of state matters weakened Republican policies in Tennessee and helped white conservative Democrats rebound politically. He lost a majority of support and left politics when his term ended in October 1871. He spent the rest of his life on his farm. Senter died on June 14, 1898. He was married to Harriet Senter and had no children. He is buried in Emma Jarnigan Cemetery in Morristown, Tennessee.
DeWitt Clinton Senter belonged to the following social groups:

Currently located in Hamilton County, Tennessee, Chattanooga was founded as early as 1816 in what was then Rhea County under the name Ross's Landing and was renamed Chattanooga in 1839. When Hamilton County was created on October 25, 1819, Chattanooga became the county seat. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: Businesses associated with creating and maintaining a system of vehicles such as trains that operate at regular times on fixed routes and are used by the public. (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A train station" or "a place where goods are kept until they are sent somewhere to be used sold, etc." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A system of transportation using special vehicles whose wheels turn on metal bars fixed to the ground, or a particular company using such a system." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.term: Railroads and Railroad Companies--Alabama and Tennessee River Railroad (Ala.)

gloss.p: Located in Alabama, the Alabama and Tennessee River Railroad was incorporated on March 4, 1868 and originally included 135 miles of rail between Selma, Alabama and Blue Mountain, Alabama, eventually adding 22 miles of rail from Blue Mountain toward Dalton, Georgia, in 1862. On August 6, 1866, the Alabama and Tennessee River Rail Road Company consolidated with the Georgia and Alabama Rail Road Company and the Dalton and Jacksonville Railroad Company to form the Selma, Rome and Dalton Railroad Company, effectively terminating the tenure of the Alabama and Tennessee River Railroad. (Wikipedia)
"The crime of illegally taking something that belongs to someone else." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)
"The act of officially choosing someone for a job, or the job itself." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An official who is responsible for prisoners who are appearing in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A public officer who judges local and less important legal cases, and performs marriage ceremonies." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A court of equity in some US states." (Cambridge Dictionary)

element.label: Description
element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Alcorn Collection. Legal document from the State of Tennessee to the State of Mississippi for the arrest of several individuals who are wanted in Tennessee and are believed to be hiding out in Mississippi.

element.label: Digital collection
element.value: Mississippi Department of Archives and History.

div.p:
State of Tennessee
Hamilton County

On this 5th day of July one thousand eight hundred and seventy one before me A A Pearson one of the acting Justices of the Peace within and for the County and State aforesaid person-ally appeared H U Smith and made oath in due form of law ^that^ Levi Hom-er, Thomas J. Hill, Thomas S Giese and J. A. Childs did on the 16th day of June 1871 in the said County of Hamilton and State of Tennessee unlawfully, malicously feloneoisly and forcibly seize take and carry away one Engine known as The " Mazeppa" one bagg-age car and Express Car one first class passenger car, from and out of the yard, of the Alabama & Chattanooga Rail Road
div.note: Editor / Reviewer: The "Mazeppa" referred to in this may be a type of railway locomotive also called a "Crab".

div.p: Company, in said County of the value of thirteen thousand dollars, and carry them into the State of Mississippi, late, the property of the said Alabama and Chattanooga Rail Road Company, but which were in the cus-tody and possession of James A. Caldwell Clerk & Master of the Chancery Court at Chattanooga Tennessee by virtue of his appointment as Receiver in various suits in ^the^ Chancery court at Chattanooga Tennessee in which said engine and cars were attached with intent to willfully fraudently and muli-ciously and felonously to deprive the owners thereof contrary to law and he prays his Excell-ency Dewitt W. C. Senter governor of the State

of Tennessee, to appoint [gap] agent to dem-and the said Levi Homer, Thomas J. Hill, Thom-as S. Geise and J. A. Childs of and from his Excell-ency The Governor of the State of Mississippi, to the end that they may be arrested and brought to the State of Tennessee so that they may be dealt with as the law requires in such cases. Said defendants are in the State of Mississippi
Sworn to & subscribed before me A A Peirson on this 5th day of July 1871 } Sct.
A A Pearson J. Peace for Hamilton County Tenn'',,

State of Tennessee
Hamilton County

I J. H. Hardie Clerk of the County Court in and for said County and State aforesaid do hereby Certify that A A Pearson Esq whose Genuine Signature appears to the within Affidavit is, and was at the time of Signing the Same an Acting Justice of the Peace for said County, duly Commissioned and qualified according to law, and that full faith, and Credit is due to his Official Acts as such.
[seal]
In witness whereof I have hereunto set my hand & Affixed the Seal of said Court of Office this 5th day of July 1871
J H Hardie Clerk
Clerks fee 50 cts. Paid

State of Tennessee
Hamilton County
To any lawful officer of said County to execute & return

Wheras complaint has oath been made to me on oath that, Levi Homer, Thomas J. Hill Thomas S Giese & J A Childs were on The 16th day of June, in the County and State aforesaid guilty of willfully, malicious-ly and felonously seizing taking and carring away one Steamer Engine, known as the "Mazeppa?" one baggage & Express Car and one first class Passenger Car of the value of thirteen thousand dollars with intent to deprive the owners of the same They having been lately the property of the Alabama & Chattanooga Rail Road Com-pany and ^then^ in the possession and control and the property of James A. Caldwell Clerk & Master of the Chancery Court at Chattanooga Tennessee
by virtue of his appoint-ment as Receiver in vari-ous suits instituted in said Chancery Court at Chatta-nooga Tennessee against the Alabama and Chatta-nooga Rail Road Company & others.

I therefore Command you to forthwith bring the said Levi Homer, Thomas J Hill, Thomas S Giese and A J Childs before me or some other Justice of the Peace for said county to be dealt with as the law requires in such cases when and where you will make known how you have executed this writ
Witness my hand & seal this 5th day of July 1871

A. A. Pearson [image: seal]
Justice of the Peace
for Hamilton County
Tennessee
Warrant

The State
vs
Linn Homer Thomas J Hill Thomas S Giese & A J Childs
[?] July 5th 1871 A A Pearson J, P, Came to hand same day issued search made & the Defendants not to be found in my County July 5th 1871

A. Bloom?
—Shff
